Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: WeInvestigate: Collaborative exploration of scientific phenomena with the assistance of hand-held simulations, prose, and graphics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The PIs are proposing an EAGER to assist in the development and study of WeInvestigate, an application that will run on a mobile device. The application will help support learners as they engage in artifact construction using multiple media while two or more learners can be synchronously collaborating either face-to-face or at a distance. WeInvestigate is leveraging the research that learning in collaboration with others associated with higher engagement and learning outcomes. The PIs are investigating the experiences of teachers and students as they implement WeInvestigate to support their engagement and learning about scientific phenomena. They are also looking at the value-added of the support for synchronous collaboration and its impact on student learning. The WeInvestigate application has the potential to reach a high number of students since it is likely that more schools have access to mobile devices and college readiness standards will be looking for collaborative tools such as WeInvesitgage that integrate collaboration and the reading of complex text. PIs are partnering with the National Science Teachers Association (NSTA) who are building a platform to support the applications for the Next Generation Science Standards.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the award of this EAGER grant, we developed and tested a standards-based science unit of instruction on matter and molecules and phase changes. The curriculum was embedded in a hand-held mobile device (Android) that each student used. The devices were linked so that students could collaborate in real time in the use of the applications, which supported joint: reading, writing, viewing of scientific simuations, viewing of video clips of phenomena,and modeling.In Year 1 of the grant, we conducted a feasbility study in a 6th grade classroom that is striving to demonstrate improved academic attainment in science. We collected pre- and post- data on content learning and we conducted case studies of three pairs of students as they worked with the tablets over four weeks. The study revealed a number of findings: there were statistically and edcuationally meaningful gains from pre- to post-test; as the teacher became increasingly comfortable with the technology, she encouraged its use as it had been designed; the collabroation among the students was uneven within and across the applications, with the most productive collaboration occuring when the students were using the WeModel application. Other findings were useful to refining parts of the curriculum for the second study.

Study 2 was an experimental study conducted in a middle school with four 6th grade classes; three of the classes used the mobile device with the same applications described above, while a fourth class learned the same curriculum, but without access to the device.  Collaboration occurred across all conditions. Pre- and post-assessment data of content knowledge were collected; in addition, we are analzying all of the student artifacts generated over the course of instruction. Finally, we surveyed the students in all classes regarding their experiences with the curriculum/technology (in the three classes) and conducted focus groups to learn more about the students' evaluation of the technology. There were no statistically signifcant differences on the pre-assessment across the four classrooms; there were statistically significant pre-post gains across all classrooms, and there were no statistically significant differences in the gains of the groups using the technology and the paper version of the curriculum. The users reported that the use of the technology supported their collaboration, made their work "easier" and "more fun and interesting."  The project team is currently conducting close study of collaborative pairs to determine if there were indeed differences in the talk, in the process products, and in the final products as a function of the modality with which the students collaborated.  In addition, we are studying the teachers's use of the curriculum and technology for the purpose of informing the design of future supports that will be incorporated in the technology in future work.
